title-group.article-title: Urinary Organophosphate Insecticide Metabolite Concentrations during Pregnancy and Children’s Interpersonal, Communication, Repetitive, and Stereotypic Behaviors at 8 Years of Age: The HOME Study

article-meta.aff: aDepartment of Epidemiology, Brown University, Providence, RI
bDivision of Laboratory Sciences, National Center for Environmental Health, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Atlanta, Georgia, USA
cDepartment of Environmental Health, Emory University, Atlanta, GA
dInstitute of Statistical Science, Academia Sinica, Taipei, Taiwan
eDepartment of Environmental Health, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, OH

gDepartment of Pediatrics, Cincinnati Children’s Hospital Medical Center, Cincinnati, OH

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding author. Joseph M. Braun Department of Epidemiology Box G-S121-2 Brown University Providence, RI 02912. joseph_braun_1@brown.edu

fn.p: The authors declare no conflict of interest. The findings and conclusions in this report are those of the authors and do not necessarily represent the views of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Use of trade names is for identification only and does not imply endorsement by the CDC, the Public Health Service, or the US Department of Health and Human Services.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Prenatal exposure to organophosphate insecticides may be associated with autism spectrum disorders and related behaviors. This association may be modified by single nucleotide polymorphisms in the paraoxonase (PON1) enzyme.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: We examined the relationship of prenatal organophosphate insecticide biomarkers with reciprocal social, repetitive, and stereotypic behaviors in 8-year old children, and modification of this relationship by child PON1 polymorphisms.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Among 224 pregnant women, we quantified concentrations of six nonspecific dialkyl phosphate (DAP) metabolites of organophosphate insecticides in two urine samples collected at ~16 and ~26 weeks gestation. When children were eight years old, we administered the Social Responsiveness Scale (SRS), a continuous measure of various dimensions of interpersonal behavior, communication, and repetitive/stereotypic behaviors. We estimated the association between a 10-fold increase in the sum of six DAP concentrations (ΣDAP) and SRS scores. We examined whether child PON1192 and PON1−108 genotypes modified this association.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: After covariate adjustment, ΣDAP concentrations were not associated with SRS scores [β = −1.2; 95% confidence interval (CI): −4.0, 1.6]. Among children with the PON1−108TT genotype, ΣDAP concentrations were associated with 2.5-point higher (95% CI: −4.9, 9.8) SRS scores; however, the association was not different from the 1.8-point decrease (95% CI: −5.8, 2.2) among children with PON1−108CT/CC genotypes (ΣDAP × PON1−108 p-value = 0.54). The association between ΣDAP concentrations and SRS scores was not modified by PON1192 (ΣDAP × PON1192 p-value = 0.89).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this cohort, prenatal urinary DAP concentrations were not associated with children’s social behaviors; these associations were not modified by child PON1 genotype.
